   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.3/40.9/1.9, ALT / AST:[**1-/2121**], Alk Phos / T
   Bili:49/1.1, Differential-Neuts:55.0 %, Band:3.0 %, Lymph:11.0 %,
   Mono:22.0 %, Eos:0.0 %, Lactic Acid:3.2 mmol/L, Albumin:2.5 g/dL,
   LDH:912 IU/L, Ca++:7.0 mg/dL, Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:5.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), OTHER
   Assessment: This is a 79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP,
   atrial fibrillation, h/o duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with
   leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b
   c.diff who developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning
   for free air and is now s/p right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   Plan:
   # Sepsis - Currently has leukocytosis, hypotensive, tachycardia.  Has
   many likely sources such as c.diff, blood (PICC in place), urine, PNA,
   but now with bowel perforation s/p colectommy and also with potentially
   a duodenoal perforation
   - Central venous line
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 12-15
   - LR boluses to keep CVP up, also to improve UOP
   - cipro, flagyl IV.  also vanco IV for MRSA cellulitis.  Cannot do PO
   vanco right now given surgery and concern for duodenal perforation
   - blood/urine/sputum cultures
   - repeat CXR
   - norepinephrine for goal MAP>60.  will also add vasopressin to help
   decrease norepinephrine dose which will only worsen tachycardia
   - serial abdominal exam; low threshold to d/w surgery for repeat look
   in abdomen if necessary
   - consider removal of PICC in AM
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure.
   CXR with significant pulm edema and Right pleural effusion. ? left
   pleural effusion.  Likely partly secondary to pulmonary edema in the
   setting of RVR and significant MR.  Also, could be developing ARDS in
   the setting of perforated bowel.
   - currently not using ARDSnet settings
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]: creatinine up to 1.4, but currently anuric post operatively.
   Likely mostly pre-renal.  [**Month (only) 11**] develop ATN secondary to hypotension.
   - IVFs to keep CVP>15
   - monitor lytes
   - urine lytes if cr continues to go up
   - dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable
   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - cannot give PO vanco for now; cont with IV flagyl
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis: day #2 after dacogen completed.  Likely counts
   will begin to drop further in the next few days
   - tx to keep HCT>30 for now
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - hold off on esmolol or dilt gtt as these can both cause hypotension
   - try vasopressive for BP and decrease norepinephrine as tolerated
   - consider dig loading
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left axillary a-line.  left PICC
   # PPx: hep sc, ppi IV
   # Code: FULL CODE
   # Dispo: ICU
   # Comm: Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4140**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2157-3-21**] 08:00 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2157-3-21**] 08:00 PM
   PICC Line - [**2157-3-21**] 08:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2157-3-21**] 08:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and a recent diagnosis of leukemia cutis/AML. He developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air, which led to a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient is currently suffering from severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and C. difficile infection.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.4°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 123 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 100/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Central venous pressure: 7 mmHg

The patient has multiple lines and tubes in place, including an arterial line, multi-lumen line, PICC line, and endotracheal tube. He is receiving various medications, including vasopressors, antibiotics, and sedatives.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 62.8 cells/μL
* Hematocrit: 35.9%
* Platelet count: 107 cells/μL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 25 mg/dL
* Serum albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.2 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.6 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Overweight/obese
* Endotracheal tube and OG tube in place
* Cardiovascular examination: normal heart sounds, no murmurs
* Peripheral vascular examination: diminished radial and dorsalis pedis pulses
* Respiratory/chest examination: symmetric expansion, crackles on left side
* Abdominal examination: distended, no bowel sounds present
* Neurological examination: sedated, unable to assess movement or tone

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure and potential development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute kidney injury and potential development of acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* C. difficile infection and potential perforation of the colon
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate and potential development of thromboembolic complications
* Leukemia cutis/AML with potential progression to leukemia

Based on the patient's condition, the plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics and vasopressors as needed
* Maintaining central venous pressure between 12-15 mmHg
* Repeating CXR and serial abdominal exams
* Considering removal of PICC line and insertion of a new central line
* Monitoring electrolytes and adjusting medications as necessary
* Reassessing the patient's code status and disposition in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. He developed acute abdominal pain and was found to have a perforated colon, which was treated with a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient's current condition is severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. He has multiple potential sources of sepsis, including C. difficile, blood (PICC line), urine, and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.4°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 123 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 100/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 7 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 62.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 107 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 22 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.6 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray with significant pulmonary edema and right pleural effusion
* CT scan of the abdomen showing concern for free air

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* IV fluids to maintain CVP of 12-15 mmHg
* LR boluses to keep CVP up
* Antibiotics changed to vancomycin IV and PR, flagyl, and flucloxacillin
* Blood cultures (unable to obtain sputum and urine cultures)
* Repeat CT scan
* Follow-up surgery recommendations, possibly back to the operating room today
* Norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg
* Keep all lines for now with an unstable patient and no positive blood cultures
* Hct Q 8 hours
* Bladder pressures Q 4 hours per surgery recommendations
* Albumin 25 g per surgery today for volume

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and atrial fibrillation
* C. difficile colitis
* Pneumonia
* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Leukemia-related complications, including bleeding and infection
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
* Respiratory failure
* Acute kidney injury
* Sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy

The patient's overall condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and a history of duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and developed left thigh MRSA cellulitis, which progressed to acute abdominal pain with concern for free air and was subsequently treated with right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient's current condition is critical, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and sepsis. He is receiving pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 55 mmHg and has a lactate level of 4.5 mmol/L, indicating severe metabolic acidosis. He is also experiencing respiratory failure, with hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, and has a volume overload on his chest X-ray.

The patient has multiple lines in place, including an arterial line, multi-lumen line, and PICC line, and is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and anticoagulants. He is also receiving nutrition and glycemic control measures.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to bowel perforation caused by Clostridium difficile (C. diff) and may progress to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
2. Bowel perforation: The patient has a high risk of developing a second bowel perforation, which can lead to further complications and mortality.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxemia and hypercarbia.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is rising, and he is becoming anuric, which can lead to acute kidney injury and potential need for dialysis.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
6. Leukemia cutis: The patient's leukemia cutis can progress, leading to further skin and systemic complications.
7. C. diff: The patient's C. diff infection can worsen, leading to further complications and mortality.

In summary, the patient is critically ill with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and sepsis, and is at high risk of developing further complications, including bowel perforation, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, atrial fibrillation, leukemia cutis, and C. diff infection. Close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and a recent right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient is currently in the ICU due to acute abdominal pain, suspected bowel perforation, and sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.4°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 127 bpm
* Blood pressure: 99/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives. He is also receiving respiratory support through invasive ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 62.8
* Hematocrit: 35.9%
* Platelet count: 107
* Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 4.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* LDH: 912 IU/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CT scan: Severe rotation of the colon, with free air and fluid in the abdomen
* CXR: Volume overload, with bilateral infiltrates

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Sepsis: Due to suspected bowel perforation and c. diff, the patient is receiving antibiotics and vasopressors.
* Bowel perforation: The patient is at risk for a second bowel perforation, and a CT scan is planned to evaluate the extent of the damage.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving invasive ventilation and has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure.
* Renal failure: The patient is becoming anuric and is receiving IV fluids to maintain a CVP of >15 mmHg.
* AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient is receiving chemotherapy, and a bone marrow transplant is planned.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for further sepsis and organ failure if the bowel perforation is not managed promptly.
* Bowel perforation: The patient is at risk for a second bowel perforation, which can lead to further complications and mortality.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure if the invasive ventilation is not managed effectively.
* Renal failure: The patient is at risk for further renal failure if the IV fluids are not managed effectively.
* AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient is at risk for further complications from the chemotherapy and bone marrow transplant.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and mortality.

He was admitted with leukemia cutis and acute myeloid leukemia (AML), as well as left thigh MRSA cellulitis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with several potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have sepsis due to bowel perforation and C. difficile infection. He is receiving antibiotics and pressors to maintain his blood pressure.
2. Bowel perforation: The patient had a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, but a second bowel perforation was discovered on a post-operative scan. He is at risk for further complications, including peritonitis and abscess formation.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation and volume overload reduction.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, and he is becoming anuric. He is receiving IV fluids to maintain his central venous pressure (CVP) above 15 mmHg.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient has a C. difficile infection, which may be contributing to his bowel perforation.
6. AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient is receiving treatment for his AML, and his white blood cell count is being monitored.
7. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which is being managed with rate control medications.

The patient's laboratory results are notable for:

* Elevated lactate levels (4.5 mmol/L)
* Elevated creatinine levels (1.4-1.7 mg/dL)
* Elevated white blood cell count (62.8-107 K/uL)
* Elevated platelet count (107-91 K/uL)
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels (22-35 mg/dL)
* Elevated serum glucose levels (142-130 mg/dL)

The patient's imaging studies are notable for:

* A severely rotated chest X-ray (CXR) with an endotracheal tube in the high position
* A CT scan showing a bowel perforation and concern for free air

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for sepsis and C. difficile infection
* Pressors to maintain blood pressure
* Mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
* IV fluids to maintain CVP above 15 mmHg
* Renal dose medications to manage acute kidney injury
* Follow-up cultures and laboratory tests to monitor the patient's condition
* Consideration of surgery for bowel perforation and abscess formation
* Monitoring of the patient's AML/Leukemia cutis treatment and response

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and hospital course complicated by C. diff. He developed acute abdominal pain on 3/21 with CT concerning for free air and underwent right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is currently on pressors and has a lactate level of 4.5. The patient has multiple medical issues, including sepsis, bowel perforation, respiratory failure, and anuria.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to bowel perforation caused by C. diff. and line infection. The patient's lactate level of 4.5 indicates a high level of inflammation, and the presence of pressors suggests that the patient's blood pressure is not stable.
2. Bowel Perforation: The patient's bowel perforation is a critical issue, and the presence of bloody fluid being suctioned from the ET tube suggests that the patient's condition is worsening. The patient's abdominal CT scan this morning will help determine the extent of the perforation, and surgery will be necessary to repair the perforation.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's volume overload on CXR suggests that the patient's lungs are not able to expand properly, and the presence of ARDSnet indicates that the patient is at risk for acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Anuria: The patient's anuria is a critical issue, and the patient's creatinine level of 1.9 suggests that the patient's kidneys are not functioning properly. The patient's IVFs will need to be adjusted to keep the patient's CVP above 15, and the patient's medications will need to be renally dosed.
5. C. diff: The patient's C. diff infection is a critical issue, and the patient's IV flagyl will need to be continued to treat the infection. The patient's bloody stool suggests that the patient's infection is not responding to treatment, and the patient's abdominal CT scan this morning will help determine the extent of the infection.
6. AML/Leukemia Cutis: The patient's AML/leukemia cutis is a critical issue, and the patient's day 3 after dacogen completed indicates that the patient's treatment is not yet complete. The patient's follow-up counts will need to be monitored to ensure that the patient's leukemia is in remission.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR is a critical issue, and the patient's tachycardic heart rate of 130-150s suggests that the patient's heart is not functioning properly. The patient's repletion of lytes will need to be monitored to ensure that the patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and the patient's pressors will need to be adjusted to ensure that the patient's blood pressure is stable.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted with acute abdominal pain and was found to have a perforated colon with c.diff infection. He underwent surgery twice, including a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and had an abscess drainage and anastomosis of a leak.

The patient's current condition is critical, with sepsis likely due to the bowel perforation and c.diff infection. He is receiving vanc/meropenem for sepsis, IV flagyl/PR vanc and IVIG for c.diff, and pressors/IVF to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 55. He has a rising lactate level and is receiving blood/urine/sputum cultures and follow-up cultures.

The patient has respiratory failure, with hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure, volume overload on CXR, and a loculated pleural effusion on the right side. He is receiving ARDSnet and is being considered for a right CT to improve ventilation if necessary.

The patient's creatinine is continuing to rise, and he is becoming anuric, with a rising potassium level. He is receiving IVFs to keep his central venous pressure (CVP) > 15, and his medications are being renally dosed. He will likely require hemodialysis or continuous veno-venous hemofiltration in the next 24 hours.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is being treated with repletion of electrolytes and consideration of changing pressors if persistent arrhythmias occur.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to the bowel perforation and c.diff infection.
2. Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure.
3. Renal failure and acute kidney injury (AKI) due to the rising creatinine and anuria.
4. Electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, due to the patient's rising potassium level.
5. Arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation with RVR, which can progress to ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
6. Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection, due to the patient's immunocompromised state.
7. Hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the surgical site or gastrointestinal tract, due to the patient's coagulopathy and anticoagulation therapy.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his complex medical condition, with a focus on preventing and treating potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is an 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and developed acute abdominal pain with CT findings concerning for free air. He underwent right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and later repeat surgery with abscess drainage and anastomosis of a leak. He is currently critically ill, requiring multiple pressors, and has developed sepsis, bowel perforation, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to bowel perforation caused by C. difficile. This can lead to multi-organ failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Bowel Perforation: The patient's bowel perforation can lead to peritonitis, abscess formation, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure can worsen his condition, leading to respiratory arrest, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and potentially death.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's rising creatinine levels and anuria suggest acute kidney injury, which can lead to end-stage renal disease, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. C. difficile Colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis can lead to severe colitis, perforation, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen his condition, leading to heart failure, stroke, and potentially death.
7. Leukemia Cutis/AML: The patient's leukemia cutis/AML can progress to acute myeloid leukemia, leading to life-threatening complications, including bleeding, infection, and organ failure.
8. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability, requiring multiple pressors, can lead to cardiovascular collapse, shock, and potentially death.
9. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's nutritional deficiencies, including glycemic control and electrolyte imbalances, can worsen his condition, leading to organ failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
10. Infection: The patient's multiple lines, including arterial, multi-lumen, and PICC lines, increase his risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill, with multiple life-threatening complications, requiring close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further deterioration and potential death.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial
   fibrillation, h/o duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia
   cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff
   who developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free
   air and is now s/p right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock
 Likely source of infection is bowel perforation though
   differential also include c. diff, line infection, and pna.  Has
   required levophed and vasopressin, though levophed was been weaned down
   marginally over the course of day on [**3-22**].    Currently has
   leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors, tachycardia.  Patient is s/p
   colectomy and re-operation on [**3-22**] because of persistent duodenoal
   perforation.  Also had abscess drainage during procedure.
   - blood and LR to goal CVP >= 15 given PEEP of 12
   - consider albumin after blood for intravascular volume expansion b/c
   patient volume overloaded
   - norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal MAP>60
   - Per ID, Abx changed to Vanco IV and PR, [**Last Name (un) **], flagyl, fluc
   - f/u culture data
   - Hct q6hrs
   -bladder pressures Q 4hrs per surgery recs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilatory settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords)
   - continue current vent settings.  Will not attempt to weane patient
   for now
   # Coagulopathy:  Patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia,
   elevated FDPs, and active bleeding from JP drains in abdomen.
   Fibrinogen remains normal, however, so patient does not strictly meet
   parameters for DIC.  Will empirically treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - s/p vitamin K on [**2157-3-23**]
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**] but urine output increasing as of
   [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for worsening kidney function nad possible
   need for dialysis but appears to be improving.  Likely experienced ATN
   from hypoperfusion in setting of sepsis.
   - renal consult
   - IVFs to keep CVP>15
   - monitor lytes
   - dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable
   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - cont with IV flagyl, PR Vanco for now
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  day #4 after dacogen completed.  Likely counts
   will begin to drop further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>30 for now
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left axillary a-line.  left PICC
   # PPx: hep sc, ppi IV drip
   # Code: FULL CODE

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial
   fibrillation, h/o duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia
   cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff
   who developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free
   air and is now s/p right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock
 Likely source of infection is bowel perforation though
   differential also include c. diff, line infection, and pna.  Has
   required levophed and vasopressin, though levophed was been weaned down
   marginally over the course of day on [**3-22**].    Currently has
   leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors, tachycardia.  Patient is s/p
   colectomy and re-operation on [**3-22**] because of persistent duodenoal
   perforation.  Also had abscess drainage during procedure.
   - blood and LR to goal CVP >= 15 given PEEP of 12
   - consider albumin after blood for intravascular volume expansion b/c
   patient volume overloaded
   - norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal MAP>60
   - Per ID, Abx changed to Vanco IV and PR, [**Last Name (un) **], flagyl, fluc
   - f/u culture data
   - Hct q6hrs
   -bladder pressures Q 4hrs per surgery recs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilatory settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords)
   - continue current vent settings.  Will not attempt to weane patient
   for now
   # Coagulopathy:  Patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia,
   elevated FDPs, and active bleeding from JP drains in abdomen.
   Fibrinogen remains normal, however, so patient does not strictly meet
   parameters for DIC.  Will empirically treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - s/p vitamin K on [**2157-3-23**]
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**] but urine output increasing as of
   [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for worsening kidney function nad possible
   need for dialysis but appears to be improving.  Likely experienced ATN
   from hypoperfusion in setting of sepsis.
   - renal consult
   - IVFs to keep CVP>15
   - monitor lytes
   - dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable
   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - cont with IV flagyl, PR Vanco for now
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  day #4 after dacogen completed.  Likely counts
   will begin to drop further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>30 for now
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left axillary a-line.  left PICC
   # PPx: hep sc, ppi IV drip
   # Code: FULL CODE

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, admitted with leukemia cutis and AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff infection. He developed acute abdominal pain with CT scan showing free air, leading to right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is currently in the ICU with septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient is at risk of further deterioration due to persistent sepsis and hypotension. Close monitoring of vital signs and hemodynamic parameters is essential.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, with hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure. He may require further ventilatory support and monitoring.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, with elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia, and active bleeding from JP drains. Close monitoring of coagulation parameters and empirical treatment for DIC are necessary.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's kidney function is compromised, with oliguric phase and possible need for dialysis. Close monitoring of kidney function and electrolyte levels is essential.
5. C.diff Infection: The patient's C.diff infection may have contributed to the perforated colon and ongoing sepsis. Close monitoring of C.diff symptoms and treatment are necessary.
6. AML/Leukemia Cutis: The patient's AML treatment may cause further bone marrow suppression and bleeding complications. Close monitoring of blood counts and platelet levels is essential.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient's tachycardia may worsen his hemodynamic status and increase the risk of cardiac complications. Close monitoring of cardiac rhythm and electrolyte levels is essential.

Recommendations:

1. Continue sepsis management with antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluid resuscitation.
2. Monitor respiratory status closely and adjust ventilatory settings as necessary.
3. Manage coagulopathy with empirical treatment for DIC and close monitoring of coagulation parameters.
4. Monitor kidney function closely and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Continue C.diff treatment and monitor symptoms closely.
6. Monitor AML/Leukemia Cutis treatment and blood counts closely.
7. Monitor atrial fibrillation with RVR and adjust electrolyte levels as necessary.

The patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further complications and improve his overall condition.

   cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff

   # Sepsis - Currently has leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors,

   place), urine, PNA, but now with bowel perforation s/p colectomy and
   also with potentially a duodenoal perforation. Has been anuric with
   just 20 cc since arrival to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] from OR. Overnight [**Last Name (un) **] stim normal
   from 30-38 . Thus, no need for steroids at this time.
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 12-15
   - LR boluses to keep CVP up
   - Per ID, Abx changed to Vanco IV and PR, [**Last Name (un) **], flagyl, fluc

   -F/u surgery recs- possibly back to OR today
   - norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal MAP>60. Have not yet needed

   - keep all lines for now with unstable pt and no + ve blood cx
   -Hct Q 8hrs

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff. He developed acute abdominal pain and was found to have free air on CT scan, leading to a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. The patient has multiple medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has multiple potential sources of sepsis, including c.diff, blood, urine, and PNA. He is currently receiving antibiotics and has been anuric with just 20cc of urine output since admission.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure and significant pulmonary edema and pleural effusions on CXR. He may be developing ARDS secondary to perforated bowel.
3. Coagulopathy/DIC: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.4 and is anuric post-operatively, likely due to pre-renal azotemia. He may develop ATN secondary to hypotension and pressors.
4. C.diff: The patient has a history of c.diff and may have perforated colon as a result.
5. AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient has AML and is at risk for bleeding and infection.
6. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR and is at risk for stroke and cardiac arrest.
7. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has acute kidney injury and is at risk for further decline in renal function.
8. Gastrointestinal Perforation: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal perforation and is at risk for further complications, including peritonitis and abscess formation.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Sepsis: IV fluids to goal CVP 12-15, LR boluses to keep CVP up, and antibiotics changed to Vanco IV and PR, flagyl, and fluconazole.
2. Respiratory Failure: CXR with significant pulmonary edema and pleural effusions, consider chest tube PRN, bronch today, and push in ETT 2 cm today.
3. Coagulopathy/DIC: IVFs to keep CVP>15, monitor lytes, and dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable.
4. C.diff: Cont with IV flagyl, PR Vanco for now, and surgery following.
5. AML/Leukemia cutis: tx to keep HCT>30 for now, tx to keep plts >50K, and BMT recs.
6. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: Hold nodal agents for now, no amio for now, and consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed by amio gtt if becomes acutely unstable.
7. Acute Kidney Injury: IVFs to keep CVP>15, monitor lytes, and dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable.
8. Gastrointestinal Perforation: Consider surgery following, and monitor for signs of peritonitis and abscess formation.

Summary:

The patient is an 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and a history of duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with leukemia cutis and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and developed acute abdominal pain on day 3 with computed tomography (CT) concerning for free air. He underwent right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and was found to have a second perforation, which was drained via abscess drainage and drains placed in the leak. The patient has developed sepsis, hypotension, and respiratory failure, and is receiving vasopressors and antibiotics. He also has coagulopathy, likely due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and chemotherapy, and is at risk for further bleeding. The patient's creatinine and potassium levels are stable, and his urine output is improving. He is also at risk for further complications, including c. difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, and stress ulceration.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to the bowel perforation and is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to the bowel perforation and the volume overload on his chest CT. He is at risk for further respiratory compromise.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely due to DIC and chemotherapy, and he is at risk for further bleeding.
4. C. difficile Infection: The patient's c. difficile infection is likely due to the antibiotics he has received and is at risk for further complications.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is at risk for further complications, including stroke and heart failure.
6. Stress Ulceration: The patient is at risk for stress ulceration due to his critical illness and is receiving prophylactic therapy.
7. Bowel Perforation: The patient's bowel perforation is at risk for further complications, including peritonitis and abscess formation.
8. Leukemia Cutis: The patient's leukemia cutis is at risk for further progression and is at risk for complications, including bleeding and infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and vasopressors as ordered.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's coagulation status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Continue c. difficile infection therapy as ordered.
5. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue stress ulcer prophylaxis as ordered.
7. Monitor the patient's bowel perforation status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's leukemia cutis status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and a history of duodenal ulcer s/p surgery. He was admitted with acute abdominal pain and was found to have a second duodenal perforation, which required repeat surgery with abscess drainage and drains placed in the leak.

The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient is on two pressors and has a history of bowel perforation, which is likely the cause of his sepsis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure, with a volume overload on CXR and a loculated pleural effusion on the right side.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has likely developed DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) due to his chemotherapy and has additional hits to his platelets from chemo.
4. Bowel Perforation: The patient has had two surgeries for bowel perforation and has drains placed in the leak.
5. C. diff: The patient has a history of C. diff and is currently being treated with IV flagyl.
6. AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient is on day 4 after dacogen completion and is awaiting a bone marrow transplant.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which is being treated with lytes and consideration for changing pressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Worsening sepsis and septic shock
2. Respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
3. Coagulopathy and bleeding complications
4. Bowel obstruction or perforation
5. C. diff colitis and diarrhea
6. Leukemia relapse or progression
7. Atrial fibrillation and stroke

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Vanc/meropenem for sepsis
2. IV flagyl and IVIG for C. diff
3. F/U cultures
4. Pressors to maintain MAP > 55
5. F/u blood/urine/sputum cultures
6. Follow fever curve
7. PRBC as needed

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Nutrition: The patient's nutrition plan is not specified in the note.
2. Glycemic Control: The patient's blood glucose levels are not specified in the note.
3. Lines: The patient has an arterial line, multi-lumen line, PICC line, and 20-gauge line.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving DVT prophylaxis with boots and SQ UF heparin, and stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI gtt.

   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. Then found to have second perf and
   now s/p repeat surgery with abscess drainage and anastomosis of leak.

 Most likely due to bowel perforation [**3-7**] c. diff.  On 2
   pressors.  S/p surgery x2.  Lactate rising.

   - F/U cultures
   - Pressors/IVF to maintain MAP > 55
   - blood/urine/sputum cultures

   suctioned from ET tube this am
   - Surgery following
   - Serial Hcts.
   - Follow bladder pressures
   # Respiratory Failure: hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure.
   Volume overload on CXR.  Chest CT with complete collapse of right lung
   s/p bronch with tube placement fixed and suctioning of R mainstem.
   Loculated pleural effusion on R.

   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - IV flagyl / PR vanc / IVIG
   # AML/Leukemia cutis: day #3 after dacogen completed.
   - Follow counts
   - BMT following
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and developed acute abdominal pain. He underwent two surgeries, including a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and is currently receiving treatment for sepsis, bowel perforation, and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of septic shock and multi-organ failure due to the presence of multiple antibiotics and pressors.
2. Bowel Perforation: The patient has a high risk of further bowel perforation and subsequent sepsis, given his history of c. diff and recent surgeries.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk of further respiratory compromise due to his underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and the presence of a loculated pleural effusion on the right side.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine is rising, and he is becoming anuric, indicating a high risk of acute kidney injury.
5. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's potassium levels are rising, and he is at risk of developing life-threatening arrhythmias.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is persistent, and he is at risk of developing further arrhythmias, particularly if his electrolytes are not repleted.
7. C. Difficile: The patient is at risk of further c. difficile infections, given his recent antibiotic use and history of c. diff.
8. Leukemia Cutis/AML: The patient's leukemia cutis/AML is progressing, and he is at risk of developing further complications, such as bleeding or infection.
9. Pressure Ulcers: The patient is at risk of developing pressure ulcers due to his prolonged immobility and the presence of multiple lines and tubes.
10. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient is at risk of developing venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to his immobility and the presence of multiple lines and tubes.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and multiple comorbidities, it is essential to closely monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent further complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation, and a history of duodenal ulcer surgery. He was admitted with acute abdominal pain and was found to have a second duodenal perforation, requiring repeat surgery with abscess drainage.

The patient is currently experiencing sepsis, with a lactate trending down after the second surgery. He is on two pressors, norepinephrine and fentanyl, and is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem, for sepsis. He also has respiratory failure, with hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, and is on a ventilator with a FiO2 of 60%. His chest CT shows complete collapse of the right lung and a loculated pleural effusion on the right.

The patient has a coagulopathy, likely due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and chemotherapy. He is receiving platelet transfusions and fresh frozen plasma as needed. He also has bowel perforation, with serial Hcts and follow-up of bladder pressures.

Other issues include C. difficile colitis, which may have caused the perforated colon, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which has resolved after surgery. He is also experiencing acute kidney injury, with a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL, and is receiving hemodialysis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis: worsening of sepsis, development of multi-organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
2. Respiratory failure: further deterioration of lung function, development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and increased risk of mortality.
3. Coagulopathy: worsening of bleeding, development of hemorrhagic shock, and increased risk of mortality.
4. Bowel perforation: further perforation, development of peritonitis, and increased risk of mortality.
5. C. difficile colitis: worsening of colitis, development of toxic megacolon, and increased risk of mortality.
6. Atrial fibrillation: development of cardiac arrhythmias, worsening of heart failure, and increased risk of mortality.
7. Acute kidney injury: worsening of kidney function, development of acute kidney failure, and increased risk of mortality.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff. He developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilatory support with a CXR showing pulmonary edema and pleural effusions, and may be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated bowel. He is currently on stable ventilatory settings.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, and is receiving norepinephrine and vasopressin to maintain a MAP of 60. His blood pressure is 84/48 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic: The patient has a CVP of 14 mmHg and is receiving blood and LR to goal CVP of 15.
* Coagulation: The patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia, and elevated FDPs, and is being treated empirically for DIC.
* Renal: The patient was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**] but urine output is increasing as of [**2157-3-23**]. He is at risk for worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis.
* Infectious: The patient has c.diff and is being treated with IV flagyl and PR Vanco. He also has MRSA cellulitis and is being treated with antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction (e.g. acute kidney injury, respiratory failure)
* Coagulopathy-related bleeding
* Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
* Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g. atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response)
* Infection-related complications (e.g. sepsis, c.diff)
* Gastrointestinal complications (e.g. perforated bowel, ileus)
* Renal failure requiring dialysis
* Cardiovascular complications (e.g. cardiogenic shock)

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for c.diff and MRSA cellulitis
* Blood and LR to goal CVP of 15
* Norepinephrine and vasopressin to maintain a MAP of 60
* Empirical treatment for DIC
* Renal consult and IVFs to keep CVP >15
* Monitoring of electrolytes and creatinine
* Dose adjustment of vancomycin based on creatinine level
* Follow-up with oncology and cardiology services
* Continued respiratory support and monitoring of vital signs.

   Assessment and Plan
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock
 Likely source of infection is bowel perforation though
   differential also include c. diff, line infection, and pna.  Has
   required levophed and vasopressin, though levophed was been weaned down
   marginally over the course of day on [**3-22**].    Currently has
   leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors, tachycardia.  Patient is s/p
   colectomy and re-operation on [**3-22**] because of persistent duodenoal
   perforation.  Also had abscess drainage during procedure and JPs placed
   in lesser sac (JP2 is most superficial in the lesser sac, JP1 is
   intermediate, and JP3 is deepest).
   - blood, platelets, albumin 25% (25g), and LR to goal CVP >= 14 given
   PEEP of 12
   - consider albumin after blood for intravascular volume expansion b/c
   patient volume overloaded
   - norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal MAP>60 but will attempt to
   wean vasopressin per surgery
   - Per ID, Abx changed to Vanco IV and PR, [**Last Name (un) **], flagyl, fluc
   - f/u culture data
   - Hct q6hrs
   - bladder pressures Q 4hrs per surgery recs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.
   - mild alkalemia on ABG this a.m. so will decrease RR, keep Vt at
   550cc, and recheck ABG
   - s/p bronch on [**2157-3-24**] with results as described above
   # Coagulopathy:  Patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia,
   elevated FDPs, and active bleeding from JP drains in abdomen.
   Fibrinogen remains normal, however, so patient does not strictly meet
   parameters for DIC.  Will empirically treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - IVFs to keep CVP>14
   - monitor lytes
   - dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable
   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - cont with IV flagyl, PR Vanco for now
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  day #5 after dacogen completed.  Likely counts
   will begin to drop further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery, though oncology
   prefers transfusion for Hct>27
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left axillary a-line.  left PICC
   # Code: FULL CODE
   # Dispo: ICU
   # Comm: Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4140**]

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML and left thigh MRSA cellulitis. He developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. He is currently in the ICU with septic shock, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, acute tubular necrosis, and C. difficile infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's blood pressure is still hypotensive, and he is receiving two pressors. He may require further interventions to maintain adequate blood pressure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further adjustments to his ventilator settings. The development of ARDS is a concern, and the patient may require invasive mechanical ventilation.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation parameters are abnormal, and he is at risk for further bleeding. He may require further transfusions and empiric treatment for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
4. Acute Tubular Necrosis: The patient's kidney function is still compromised, and he may require further management with dialysis or other renal replacement therapies.
5. C. difficile Infection: The patient's C. difficile infection is ongoing, and he may require further treatment with antibiotics and other measures to control the infection.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is ongoing, and he may require further management with anti-arrhythmic medications or cardioversion.
7. Leukemia Cutis/AML: The patient's leukemia cutis/AML is ongoing, and he may require further treatment with chemotherapy or other therapies to manage the disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his pressor therapy as needed.
2. Adjust the patient's ventilator settings to optimize his respiratory status and prevent further respiratory failure.
3. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy with transfusions and empiric treatment for DIC.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his management accordingly.
5. Continue to manage the patient's C. difficile infection with antibiotics and other measures.
6. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with anti-arrhythmic medications or cardioversion as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's leukemia cutis/AML and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy. Then found to have second perf and
   now s/p repeat surgery with abscess drainage and drains placed in
   leak.

 Most likely due to bowel perforation [**3-7**] c.
   diff.  On 2 pressors.  S/p surgery x2.  Improved after second surgery
   with lactate trending down.  Now with falling Hct and serosangunous

Based on the patient's progress note, the following are the key findings and potential medical complications:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and developed acute abdominal pain.
* He has undergone two surgeries, including a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and has been diagnosed with bowel perforation, c.diff infection, and possible DIC.
* He is currently receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and anticoagulants, and is being monitored for sepsis, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and bowel perforation.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Sepsis/Hypotension:** The patient's sepsis is likely due to bowel perforation and c.diff infection, and he is being treated with vasopressors. There is a risk of further deterioration in his condition if the infection is not effectively managed.
2. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is likely related to his underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further respiratory decline if the patient's condition does not improve.
3. **Coagulopathy:** The patient has likely developed DIC, which is a serious condition that can lead to bleeding and other complications. Monitoring of coagulation studies and administration of clotting factors will be necessary to manage this condition.
4. **Bowel Perforation:** The patient has undergone surgery to repair the bowel perforation, but there is a risk of further complications, including infection and abscess formation.
5. **C.diff Infection:** The patient has been diagnosed with c.diff infection, which is a serious condition that can lead to further complications, including perforated colon and sepsis.
6. **Atrial Fibrillation:** The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which can lead to further complications, including stroke and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. **Leukemia Cutis/AML:** The patient has ongoing leukemia cutis/AML, which can lead to further complications, including bone marrow failure and bleeding.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy as necessary to manage his sepsis, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, bowel perforation, c.diff infection, and atrial fibrillation.
* Consider adding caspofungin to the patient's antibiotic regimen to cover for possible fungal infections.
* Continue to follow the patient's laboratory values, including coagulation studies, and administer clotting factors as necessary to manage his coagulopathy.
* Monitor the patient's bowel output and adjust his fluid management accordingly to prevent further complications.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his fluid management accordingly to prevent further complications.
* Consider consulting with infectious disease and hematology specialists to further manage the patient's condition.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of MRSA cellulitis, c. diff, and bowel perforation, which increases the risk of developing sepsis. The patient is already on two pressors and has a falling Hct, which may indicate ongoing infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is likely due to volume overload and loculated pleural effusion. Weaning FiO2 and correcting alkalosis may be necessary.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has a history of DIC and is at risk of further bleeding due to the ongoing chemotherapy and surgical drains. Monitoring DIC labs and administering platelets, FFP, and cryoprecipitate as needed may be necessary.
4. Bowel Perforation: The patient has already undergone two surgeries to address bowel perforation, and further surgery may be necessary to manage the ongoing leak.
5. C. diff: The patient has c. diff, which may be contributing to the patient's ongoing abdominal pain and bleeding.
6. AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient has AML and leukemia cutis, which may be affecting the patient's blood counts and increasing the risk of bleeding and infection.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which may increase the risk of arrhythmias and cardiac complications.
8. Somnolence: The patient is sedated, and weaning off sedation may be necessary to assess the patient's neurological status.
9. Nutritional Deficits: The patient is critically ill and may be at risk of nutritional deficits, which may require aggressive nutritional support.
10. Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has a history of volume overload and electrolyte imbalances, which may require careful monitoring and management.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to continue monitoring and managing these potential complications closely to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcome.

 Most likely due to bowel perforation [**3-7**] c.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer s/p surgery. He has been admitted with acute abdominal pain and was found to have bowel perforation, which led to sepsis, hypotension, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs:
	+ Temperature: 102.2°F (39°C)
	+ Heart rate: 88 beats per minute (bpm)
	+ Blood pressure: 99/54 mmHg
	+ Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
	+ Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Laboratory results:
	+ White blood cell count: 23.2 x 10^9/L
	+ Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
	+ Platelet count: 107 x 10^9/L
	+ Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
	+ Potassium: 4.3 mEq/L
	+ Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
	+ Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
	+ LDH: 607 IU/L
* Imaging results:
	+ CXR: Rotated, volume loss on right, ET tube in good position, bilateral effusions, and bilateral airspace disease
	+ CT: Concerning for free air and bowel perforation
* Medical issues:
	+ Sepsis/hypotension: Most likely due to bowel perforation
	+ Respiratory failure: Hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
	+ Coagulopathy: Likely DIC with additional hit to platelets from chemo
	+ Bowel perforation: S/p surgery
	+ C. difficile: Possibly cause of perforated colon
	+ AML/Leukemia cutis: Day #4 after dacogen completed
	+ Atrial fibrillation with RVR: On arrival, very tachycardic to 130-150s; now in NSR after surgery

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: Continued sepsis and hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Respiratory failure: Prolonged respiratory failure can lead to respiratory acidosis, hypercapnia, and hypoxemia.
* Coagulopathy: Continued coagulopathy can lead to bleeding complications and organ failure.
* Bowel perforation: Continued bowel perforation can lead to peritonitis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
* C. difficile: Continued C. difficile infection can lead to recurrent diarrhea, colitis, and sepsis.
* AML/Leukemia cutis: Continued AML/Leukemia cutis can lead to bone marrow failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bleeding complications.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: Continued atrial fibrillation with RVR can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and stroke.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 55 mmHg
* IV antibiotics for sepsis
* Consider adding caspofungin for sepsis
* IV flagyl for C. difficile
* F/U cultures
* Pressors to maintain MAP > 55 mmHg
* F/u blood/urine/sputum cultures
* Follow fever curve
* PRBC/plts as needed
* Surgery following
* Serial Hcts
* Follow bladder pressures
* Hold on CVVHD for now
* IV flagyl
* No IVIG at this time
* Follow counts
* BMT following
* Replete lytes
* If persistent arrhythmias, consider change pressors

The patient's current condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including leukemia cutis, atrial fibrillation, and a history of duodenal ulcer surgery. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with acute abdominal pain, which was found to be due to bowel perforation and c. difficile infection. He has undergone two surgeries, including a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy, and has developed a leak.

The patient is currently experiencing several medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient is on two pressors and has had two surgeries. His lactate levels are trending down, but he is still experiencing falling hemoglobin and serosanguinous fluid from his abdominal drains.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure and volume overload on his chest X-ray. He has a loculated pleural effusion on the right side and is on 50% FiO2.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has likely developed disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) due to his chemotherapy and bone marrow suppression. He is experiencing bloody output from his surgical drains.
4. Bowel Perforation: The patient has had two surgeries to repair his bowel perforation, and he will likely require further surgery.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient is being treated with IV flagyl, but is not tolerating the medication.
6. AML/Leukemia cutis: The patient is on day 4 of his chemotherapy regimen and will require further treatment.
7. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's heart rate has normalized after his surgery, but he will require close monitoring for persistent arrhythmias.
8. Somnolence: The patient is sedated, but will have his sedation weaned off soon.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 107,000/uL
* White blood cell count: 23.2/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.3 mEq/L
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 607 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: Volume loss on the right side, with an endotracheal tube in good position and bilateral effusions and airspace disease.
* CT scan: Complete collapse of the right lung, with a loculated pleural effusion on the right side.

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuing treatment for sepsis with vancomycin and meropenem
* Adding caspofungin to his antibiotic regimen
* Administering IV flagyl for c. difficile infection
* Following up on cultures and monitoring his fever curve
* Weaning his FiO2 as tolerated
* Correcting his alkalosis
* Performing bronchoscopy to inspect his airway
* Following up on his coagulopathy with platelet transfusions and cryoprecipitate as needed
* Monitoring his bowel perforation and considering further surgery
* Following up on his AML/leukemia cutis with chemotherapy and bone marrow transplantation
* Monitoring his atrial fibrillation with RVR and considering changes to his pressors
* Weaning his sedation off soon.

   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute

   # Septic shock

   required levophed and vasopressin, though levophed was been weaned down
   marginally over the course of day on [**3-22**].    Currently has
   leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors, tachycardia.  Patient is s/p
   colectomy and re-operation on [**3-22**] because of persistent duodenoal
   perforation.  Also had abscess drainage during procedure and JPs placed
   in lesser sac (JP2 is most superficial in the lesser sac, JP1 is
   intermediate, and JP3 is deepest).  Weaned off vasopressin on [**2157-3-24**].

   - f/u culture data

   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.

   elevated FDPs, and active bleeding from JP drains in abdomen.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and duodenal ulcer surgery, who was admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh MRSA cellulitis, and c.diff. He developed acute abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with a CT scan showing concerning free air and subsequently underwent a right hemicolectomy and ileostomy.

The patient is currently in the ICU with the following medical issues:

1. Septic Shock: The patient is septic with a likely source of infection being bowel perforation. He has required levophed and vasopressin, and his blood pressure and urine output are being monitored.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is being treated with mechanical ventilation. He also has pulmonary edema and pleural effusions on his CXR.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia, and elevated FDPs, which is being treated with blood and platelet transfusions.
4. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient has ATN with muddy brown casts in his urine, which is likely related to hypoperfusion in the setting of sepsis.
5. Clostridioides difficile (C.diff): The patient has C.diff, which is being treated with IV flagyl and PR vancomycin.
6. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)/Leukemia Cutis: The patient has AML/leukemia cutis, which is being treated with chemotherapy and blood transfusions.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which is being treated with norepinephrine and beta-blockers.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock can lead to organ dysfunction, including respiratory, renal, and cardiovascular failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure can worsen, leading to respiratory arrest.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's ATN can worsen, leading to acute kidney injury.
5. C.diff colitis: The patient's C.diff can lead to colitis, which can worsen his septic shock and respiratory failure.
6. Leukemia relapse: The patient's AML/leukemia cutis can relapse, leading to further complications.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR can lead to cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrest.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for his septic shock and C.diff.
2. Blood and platelet transfusions: The patient is receiving blood and platelet transfusions to treat his coagulopathy.
3. Mechanical ventilation: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation to treat his respiratory failure.
4. Norepinephrine: The patient is receiving norepinephrine to treat his septic shock.
5. Chemotherapy: The patient is receiving chemotherapy for his AML/leukemia cutis.
6. Blood pressure management: The patient's blood pressure is being monitored and managed to prevent further complications.
7. Renal function monitoring: The patient's renal function is being monitored to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   79 year-old male with a history of HTN, HLP, atrial fibrillation, h/o
   duodenal ulcer s/p surgery admitted with leukemia cutis/AML, left thigh
   MRSA cellulitis with hospital course c/b c.diff who developed acute
   abdominal pain on [**3-21**] with CT concerning for free air and is now s/p
   right hemicolectomy and ileostomy
   # Septic shock
 Likely source of infection is bowel perforation though
   differential also include c. diff, line infection, and pna.  Has
   required levophed and vasopressin, though levophed was been weaned down
   marginally over the course of day on [**3-22**].    Currently has
   leukocytosis, hypotensive on 2 pressors, tachycardia.  Patient is s/p
   colectomy and re-operation on [**3-22**] because of persistent duodenoal
   perforation.  Also had abscess drainage during procedure and JPs placed
   in lesser sac (JP2 is most superficial in the lesser sac, JP1 is
   intermediate, and JP3 is deepest).
   - blood, platelets, albumin 25% (25g), and LR to goal CVP >= 14 given
   PEEP of 12
   - consider albumin after blood for intravascular volume expansion b/c
   patient volume overloaded
   - norepinephrine and vasopressin for goal MAP>60 but will attempt to
   wean vasopressin per surgery
   - Per ID, Abx changed to Vanco IV and PR, [**Last Name (un) **], flagyl, fluc
   - f/u culture data
   - Hct q6hrs
   - bladder pressures Q 4hrs per surgery recs
   # Respiratory Failure: both hypercarbic/hypoxemic respiratory failure
   in the setting of sepsis.  CXR with pulmonary edema and pleural
   effusions.  Also, could be developing ARDS in the setting of perforated
   bowel.   Currently on stable ventilator settings.  S/p bronch on [**3-22**]
   for right lobar collapse but no mucous plug seen; aeration improved
   after advancement of ETT 2 cm (was at level of vocal chords).  S/p
   bronch on [**3-23**] for decreased right lung size but mucous plug again
   absent.
   - mild alkalemia on ABG this a.m. so will decrease RR, keep Vt at
   550cc, and recheck ABG
   - s/p bronch on [**2157-3-24**] with results as described above
   # Coagulopathy:  Patient has elevated PT/PTT, thrombocytopenia,
   elevated FDPs, and active bleeding from JP drains in abdomen.
   Fibrinogen remains normal, however, so patient does not strictly meet
   parameters for DIC.  Will empirically treat for DIC because high risk.
   - continue blood, FFP, blood transfusions as needed
   - s/p vitamin K 5mg IV x 2 on [**2157-3-23**]
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]:  ATN with muddy brown casts in urine.  Was oliguric on [**2157-3-22**]
   but urine output increasing as of [**2157-3-23**].  Concern initially for
   worsening kidney function and possible need for dialysis but UOP
   improving.  Likely experienced ATN from hypoperfusion in setting of
   sepsis.
   - f/u renal reccs
   - IVFs to keep CVP>14
   - monitor lytes
   - dose vanco by level until creatinine is stable
   # C.diff: as above; possibly cause of perforated colon.
   - cont with IV flagyl, PR Vanco for now
   - surgery following
   # AML/Leukemia cutis:  day #5 after dacogen completed.  Likely counts
   will begin to drop further in the next few days per oncology.
   - tx to keep HCT>25 based on consultation with surgery, though oncology
   prefers transfusion for Hct>27
   - tx to keep plts >50K
   - BMT recs
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: on arrival, very tachycardic to
   130-150s.  Likely all response to being septic and post operatively.
   Norepinephrine also likely culprit.  Cards consulted and do not think
   TEE followed by cardioversion indicated at this time. If becomes
   acutely unstable, consider emergent cardioversion without TEE followed
   by amio gtt.  HR stabilizing to 80-100 now.
   - hold nodal agents for now
   - no amio for now- not anticoagulated so concern for embolic even if
   spontaneously converts
   # FEN: NPO for now; IVFs as above
   - replete lytes PRN
   # Access: RIJ, left axillary a-line.  left PICC
   # Code: FULL CODE
   # Dispo: ICU
